abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Education for All (EFA)
            Fast Track Initiative Catalytic Fund Grant Project for
            Lesotho were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            significant, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            institutional assessments to gauge the capacity of not just
            the Implementing Agency but all involved players in
            implementation of project activities is critical to
            assessing the realism of project targets. A centralized
            procurement strategy for peripheral civil works, although
            counterintuitive, was more effective as it consolidated
            small and scattered bids, resulting in all classrooms and
            latrines at one school being adequately managed in one lot
            for procurement. Mid-course corrections, when done using
            strong evidence that align the scope of project activities
            and targets with IA capacity are critical once an
            implementation challenge become visible and is a strong
            justification for changing the course of a project. The Bank
            can play an important role in turning around project
            performance through intensive and proactive support when the
            situation requires. The projects implementation experience
            from the project indicates that mainstreaming Project
            Implementation Unit (PIU) activities is challenging when an
            implementing agency is weak and there continues to be a need
            for a dedicated project staff or PIU.
